perturbation.original_text: THERE ARE NO WARRANTIES WHICH EXTEND BEYOND THE PRODUCT DESCRIPTION HEREIN, AND SELLER MAKES NO WARRANTY, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, OF FITNESS FOR PARTICULAR USE, MERCHANTABILITY OR OTHERWISE WITH RESPECT TO PRODUCT, WHETHER USED SINGLY OR IN COMBINATION WITH OTHER SUBSTANCES OR IN ANY PROCESS, EXCEPT THAT PRODUCT SOLD HEREUNDER SHALL CONFORM TO SELLER'S STANDARD SALES SPECIFICATIONS AS OF THE DATE OF SHIPMENT.
perturbation.changed_text: THERE ARE NO WARRANTIES WHICH EXTEND BEYOND THE PRODUCT DESCRIPTION HEREIN, AND SELLER MAKES NO WARRANTY, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, OF FITNESS FOR PARTICULAR USE OR OTHERWISE WITH RESPECT TO PRODUCT, WHETHER USED SINGLY OR IN COMBINATION WITH OTHER SUBSTANCES OR IN ANY PROCESS, EXCEPT THAT PRODUCT SOLD HEREUNDER SHALL CONFORM TO SELLER'S STANDARD SALES SPECIFICATIONS AS OF THE DATE OF SHIPMENT.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the term 'MERCHANTABILITY', the contract eliminates the implied warranty of merchantability, which ensures that goods are of acceptable quality and fit for their ordinary purpose. This violates the implied warranty of merchantability under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), applicable in most US states, including Texas, the governing law specified in Attachment A.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) - Implied Warranty of Merchantability

perturbation.original_text: EM gives no guarantees or warranties, express or implied, as to the quality, merchantability, fitness for purpose or suitability of the products except that the product sold pursuant to the terms of this Agreement shall meet the relevant EM standard specification in force at the time of loading or such other specification or requirement which may be explicitly agreed in writing between the parties.
perturbation.changed_text: EM gives no guarantees or warranties, express or implied, as to the quality, fitness for purpose or suitability of the products except that the product sold pursuant to the terms of this Agreement shall meet the relevant EM standard specification in force at the time of loading or such other specification or requirement which may be explicitly agreed in writing between the parties.
perturbation.explanation: The term 'merchantability' is removed, which is a significant omission. Under Belgian law (the governing law as defined in section 22) and the Sale of Goods Act, goods sold must be of merchantable quality, meaning they must be fit for the purpose for which they are sold. By removing this explicit warranty, the contract attempts to circumvent this mandatory consumer protection.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Belgian Law - Sale of Goods Act (implied warranty of merchantability)

perturbation.original_text: Subject to the Clauses on Quantity, Transfer of Risk and Title Transfer, Buyer shall inspect and test product delivered hereunder for damage, defect or shortage immediately upon receipt and provide Seller notice of any such damage, defect or shortage within ten (10) days of receipt.
perturbation.changed_text: Subject to the Clauses on Quantity, Transfer of Risk and Title Transfer, Buyer shall inspect and test product delivered hereunder for damage, defect or shortage immediately upon receipt and provide Seller notice of any such damage, defect or shortage within two (2) days of receipt.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the inspection period from ten (10) days to two (2) days places an unreasonable burden on the Buyer.  Many jurisdictions provide for a 'reasonable time' for inspection, and two days for potentially complex chemical products may be deemed unreasonable, especially for international shipments where delays are common.  This could violate implied terms under Singapore law (governing law for transactions under Attachment G) relating to reasonable opportunity for inspection.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Singapore Law - Sale of Goods Act (implied terms regarding reasonable inspection period)
